ai_page.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Slough - Page
ai_page.body:
Making improvements to your council home

Before secure housing tenants can make changes and improvements to their home, they must ask for council permission. Changes you must ask us for permission for include:

  • building sheds, garages and greenhouses or putting up extra fencing
  • building an extension or conservatory
  • making changes to your garden, like constructing a pond or concreting over it
  • making changes to the electrics.

Download the request permission to make a change to your council home form.

We give permission for most home improvements, but often attach conditions which usually include you agreeing to:

  • use a competent contractor and complete the work to an acceptable standard
  • a time limit for completing the work
  • submit plans for the work
  • get building regulations approvals and planning permission
  • tell us when you’ve finished the work so we can inspect it
  • provide us with copies of certificates including electrical and building regulations.

Getting the right permissions to make changes

To make changes to your council home you must:

  • complete the permission form to get written permission from Slough Borough Council
  • check if you need to apply for planning permission
  • check if you need a building regulation application.

If you carry out any changes without permission, you will have to pay to return the property to its original condition. If you do not pay, we will have the work done and recharge you.

If permission is given to make changes

Once you have all the right permissions, you can go ahead with the work. Depending on the scale of improvements, we may want to inspect your home before and after.  You are responsible for repairing and maintaining any home improvement you make.

If you get a contractor to do the work, make sure the contractor has disposed of the rubbish correctly. Fly-tipping is a crime. If you are doing the work, dispose of your waste properly.

If permission to make changes is refused

Permission to make changes will be refused if we have a good reason. We normally prevent changes if the work will affect the safety of your building, cause a future problem with maintenance of the property, or cause nuisance to your neighbour/s.

Refusals are communicated to you in writing, either by post or email. If you disagree with our decision or the conditions we have attached, you can appeal in a letter to us.

ai_business_case.letter:
To the CEO:

Subject: Recommendations for Enhancing the Council’s Online Flat Improvement Request Service

As the web usability expert overseeing our digital services, I have reviewed the recent customer feedback and interaction data concerning the online process for applying to make changes to council flats, specifically from customer "David" in South London.

Overall, the current webpage effectively explains the process, permissions involved, and legal considerations. This positive feedback indicates that our users find the information clear and helpful. Kudos to the web team for delivering a user-friendly and informative page.

However, there are clear opportunities for targeted improvements that could significantly enhance the customer experience and operational efficiency, leading to potential cost savings and improved service delivery:

1. **Implement Direct Access to the Permission Form**:  
   Feedback from David highlights the need for a quick, accessible link or button to download the permission request form directly on the information page. By prominently placing a “Download the Permission Form” button or link near the top, we simplify the process, reduce user frustration, and decrease call or email inquiries seeking the form.  
   *Impact:* Fewer administrative queries will reduce workload, streamline processing times, and cut postage costs associated with mailed forms.

2. **Add a Step-by-Step Summary or Quick Checklist**:  
   Incorporating a simple, visual step-by-step summary or a downloadable checklist at the end of the instructions would help users confirm they understand the process. This design reduces ambiguity and errors, empowering users to complete the steps confidently, whether they choose to apply online or via mail.  
   *Impact:* This will enhance user satisfaction, reduce the number of incomplete or incorrect submissions, and streamline case handling for staff.

3. **Enhance Progress Transparency and Update Notifications**:  
   While not explicitly flagged as a problem, David’s concern about delays and missing updates suggests that providing estimated timelines and clear notification options—such as email or SMS updates—would greatly improve trust and satisfaction.  
   *Impact:* Clear expectations reduce customer anxiety and post-approval inquiries, saving staff time and fostering positive community relations.

**Summary and Recommendation**:  
By focusing on direct access to forms, clearer process summaries, and proactive communication, we can create a more intuitive and efficient online service. These enhancements should be considered as part of an ongoing usability and process improvement program, with potential to reduce administrative costs, improve turnaround times, and elevate the council’s service reputation.

Please let me know if you'd like a detailed implementation plan or additional insights.

Best regards,  
[Web Manager]  
Usability & Digital Service Lead
